scenes.location: THE SPARE ROOM BOWLING ALLEY PUEBLO, COLORADO -
characters: COUNTRY RECORD STAR / BAD BLAKE / HERE / FRIDAY, AUGUST 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAD BLAKE, fifty-seven years old, stands in the parking l in front of his 1978 Chevrolet Suburban. * Above him a sign announces: WINTER LEAGUES NOW FORMING

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY RECORD STAR / BAD BLAKE / HERE / FRIDAY, AUGUST 1
dialogues.text: Bad reaches for a Pall Mall. The pack is nearly empty, lo and slick with sweat. He lights one and looks to the sign

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Jack, you bastard. A fucking bowling alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bowling alley is full of light and smells of wax. The conditioning hits hard and turns Bad's soaked shirt icy. A single bowler works in the middle of thirty lanes. Bad hears the ball drop, the steady roll, and then the impact

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Blake! I'm proud to meet you, God. I used to listen to you when I was just a kid. Bad manages a wheeze and smile and pumps the manager's ha The MANAGER is overweight, early thirties, and all smiles

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have a good trip?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Long but good. Played Clovis, New Mexico last night. Saw some pretty country, but glad to be here.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Down there's the bandstand. The manager points to a make-shift stage: in the shadow l a drum kit and microphones.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll catch up to you later. Sure glad to have you, Bad. Makes my day. Bad moves over to the BAR. INT. THE SPARE ROOM BOWLING ALLEY - BAR — CONTINUOUS 3 * Behind the bar, enormous fish swim back and forth ina lighted aquarium. Bad calls to the BARMAID. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 2

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Darlin, bring me a J.D. up, beer back. Bad smiles and points to the fish.

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Buy one for the boys in the backroom there, too. The BARMAID, young, sullen and early twenties, doesn't sm

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: Three twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (winks ) On my tab, darlin.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: No tab.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'm Bad Blake, little darlin'. I'm the band. She turns and walks away. The manager appears at Bad's si

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake, we have a real nice room for you over in the Starlight Inn, and of course, your meals are taken care of, but I'm afraid we can't let you run a bar tab. It's in the contract. Mr. Greene of Greene and Gold put that in himself. Bad reaches out. For a second he is ready to grab the gri knob of the manager's Adam's apple and crush it. Instead, touches the man's shoulder and gently squeezes.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: If you and Jack have an agreement, we'll have to stick by it. Don't worry yourself about it, old buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the barmaid) How much?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAID
dialogues.text: Three twenty-five. Bad looks hard at the shot. He's sweating. The cigarette between his fingers is wavering. He digs four dollars fro his pocket. The barmaid leaves his change on the bar. He keeps it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 3

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake. Let me personally offer you all the free bowling you want. Bad nearly chokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is standard fare: Queen bed, small TV, sparse li Telephone in hand, Bad, shirt stripped off, runs his hand across his broad belly and groans. On the TV, a man and woman embrace. Their lips move, but sound. Bad talks to his manager, JACK GREENE, late sixtie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits behind his desk, staring out at the smoggy haze Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bad, I didn't want to tell you until you came off this swing. C.M.I. cut out "So Sweet, So Bad".

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: But that fucker was still selling.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It had slowed a lot, and the chains don't want it anymore. Plus, Tommy's got nine albums out there right now. Bad sits up and looks out into the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What about Tommy's new album? I'll be off the road in a couple of weeks. We can get right to it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Tommy wants to know if you've got new material. Bad looks to the TV. The colors are streaked and blotchy.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You know I don't have new material. And there's nothing wrong with the old stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Tommy thinks he's leaning too hard on the old stuff. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 4

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He doesn't want people to think he's riding the gravy train.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: That son-of-a-bitch has a lifetime pass on the gravy train.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Come on, Bad. Remember who's asking who to do a record here. Bad stands and moves to the window.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Jack, you jerk-off. You get out here, in Clovis, goddamned, New Mexico and play in a piano bar or a bowling alley. Get up the next fucking morning at five and drive three hundred miles with hemorrhoids so bad it feels like you've got a nest of fire ants up your ass, and then you tell me about riding the goddamned gravy train. You and Mr. Country Star Tommy Sweet both try it sometime.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Bad, calm down. Tommy says he wants new material. I'll keep talking, but he holds the cards. You know that, I know it, and Tommy Sweet sure as hell knows it.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You tell Tommy for me that he wouldn't know country music if it came up and kicked him in his world- famous ass. Jack keeps talking, and Bad puts the phone against his be and looks back at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Jack, I'm broke. I'm fifty-seven years old and I only have ten bucks to my name.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I sent you money when you were still in Texas. Plenty. So spend it wisely, Bad.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you your mother used to bite when she gave head? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I love you too, bye. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack hangs up. Bad falls heavily onto the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad stares at a fifth of JACK DANIEL'S for what seems lik eternity. As he stoops to a pint of HEAVEN HILL, his knee erack and he exhales. All accompanied by a deep sigh.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (o.8.) Mr. Blake? Bad turns and faces a man about the same age as himself.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hell fire. It is you. It really is Bad Blake right here in my store. The man reaches out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm Bill Wilson. I'm a big fan. Bad smiles and looks to the cheap bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Here. Here, Mr. Blake. Here's the Jack Daniel's. Bill pulls a full liter of J.D. off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Being a big fan and all, I kind of keep track of what the stars drink. It's kind of a hobby, you know. Willie Nelson and his Lone Star beer, Tommy Sweet and his Southern Comfort, and Bad Blake and his Jack Daniel's. Of course, I never thought I'd actually have a star right here in my store. Bad eyes the bottle in Bill's hand and wheezes with desir

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My wife, Beverly, is one of your biggest fans. She'll flat die when she finds out you were here in the store. We're going to your show tonight. If you could sing 'I Don't Know' for her, it would sure mean the world to her.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You got it, old buddy. Bad can't take his eyes off that bottle of JACK. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 6

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 'I Don't Know' for Beverly. You got it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (hands the J.D. to Bad) Here, take this. I want to be able to tell everyone that I bought Bad Blake a drink. Bad looks to the heavens and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottle of J.D. is a quarter finished. Someone pounds the door. Bad opens the door to find a young man, TONY, w long hair and a wispy beard.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Tony. Bad blinks in incomprehension.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tony. Tony and the Renegades. Your band.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: of course.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Me and the boys are over at the alley, setting up. We were wondering what time to start rehearsing.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Soon as you can and do it as often as you can. That's the secret. Bad tries to shut the door, but Tony stops him.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What I mean is, what time are you coming to rehearsal? Bad sighs and leads Tony by the arm out to his van.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I got lead sheets if you all can read music, chord charts if you can't. Cd's and a play list. You go on. I'll be by later. Bad turns for the bottle and the room. Tony follows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 7

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake, it would mean a lot to us if you would come on over early. I mean, we need to get the leads down and all that.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Leads? Son, are they paying you more than they're paying me?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: But, I thought you could show us some things, teach us some of that old stuff Bad's Boys used to do. Is it true you taught Tommy Sweet how to play guitar? Bad ignores the remark about Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: All right. You all go listen to the cd's. Listen carefully and study the lead sheets. Give me an hour to get some dinner and I'll be on over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the drab roadhouse, Bad pokes at a chicken-fried steak. Pale gravy oozes from it and blends with mashed- potatoes and corn. A WAITRESS slides into the booth acros the table from him. She exhales a long stream of cigarett smoke over his food.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Everything, okay.?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (nods) Fine. Just fine. She winks at him. A small row of mascara sticks to her lo lash. She wears a red nylon blouse and a plastic name tag that says, "Howdy, I'm Jo Ann."

dialogues.speaker: JO ANN
dialogues.text: Mind if I smoke? Bad waves his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JO ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must like to eat early and avoid the crowds. Being able to eat in peace without a bunch of people asking for autographs and stuff...Mind if I ask a question? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Shoot. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches over and taps his knuckle with a long red fingernail.

dialogues.speaker: JO ANN
dialogues.text: I always wondered if you had a good time singing those songs. Because, God, I had me a couple of real good times listening to them. Her laugh is deep and a raspy from the cigarette smoke.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Anything you want to hear tonight? She bites her tongue as she thinks. Her teeth are stained from the lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: JO ANN
dialogues.text: You do anything from that album you do with Tommy Sweet?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: A few. The standards.

dialogues.speaker: JO ANN
dialogues.text: Any of those. God, I just love that album, Memories: So Sweet, So Bad.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: So does Tommy, darlin’. She laughs that raspy laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JO ANN
dialogues.text: You two don't get along anymore?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (shrugs) What the wives didn't get off that album, Tommy did. She runs her finger up his forearm.

dialogues.speaker: JO ANN
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me your real name?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You want to know that, you got to Marry me. Otherwise, it's just Bad.  10 Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bad crosses to the stage carrying his guitar and tweed vintage FENDER amp, a rockabilly version of Bad's "I Don' Know," as played by the Renegades, swells up and staggers him. Tony and the Renegades stop as they see him approach though the drummer continues to pound for a few more beat (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 9

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I hope to God that wasn't one of my songs you were playing. Tony steps down from the stage.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake, these are the Renegades.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMER,
dialogues.text: That's it? That's your equipment? Bad unsnaps his case.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: This is it. A '59 Gretsch with an action that would put a twenty year- old whore to shame. Bad looks to their heavy, stacked Marshall amps.

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you're playing loud enough to drown out my amp, you're playing too fucking loud. At that, Tony turns to his band and strums a couple of chords. Bad digs through his case.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (moving toward Tony) You might want to bring it up a half step.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'm in tune. I got an electronic tuning meter.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I got a fifty-seven year old ear says you're off. And so their rehearsal begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guitar in hand and now wearing dark sunglasses, Bad cross to his amp and takes a seat. He begins a blues-tinted sol “Somebody Else" that causes Tony to throw a look to his b

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That ain't country. Bad looks up from his guitar. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: 9A
dialogues.text: (CONT'D) ll

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Country's just the white man's blues. Tony looks to the Renegades and then back to Bad.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Do some of that Tommy Sweet stuff for us. Bad looks to Tony and then begrudgingly obliges.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: It's just some of that cajun patois steel-bendin stuff... The boys look at one another as Bad starts in on one of h greatest hits, "I Don't Know". He runs through a break fu of hammers and pulls, the style he taught Tommy and that become Tommy's signature.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. I think Tommy plays it more like this. Tony begins the song again, throwing in double and triple pulls, trilling the high notes. The Renegades join in bombastically.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think that's more the sort of thing he does now. That's the way we like to play it.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Keep working on that because someday Tommy will be playing this very bowling alley. You'll all still be here and you can buy each other drinks, get drunk and be a couple of guitar-picking wonders. Bad cases his Gretsch.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 11 A
dialogues.text: 12 13 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours before the show. Bad watches a MEXICAN soap ope on TV, still without sound. He takes a long pull at his bottle of Jack Daniels. He's pretty lit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad struggles across the parking lot carrying his guitar one hand and his amp in the other. He's an aging man dres in his signature black boot-cut slacks, vest and white sh At the back door, Tony and the Renegades are lounging, cooling off between sets. They watch Bad lurch across the parking lot. No one offers help. Bad's wheezing hard. The air is sharp with marijuana as B watches a joint go from hand to hand.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: We were afraid you weren't going to show. The band members look at each other, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Son, I've played sick, drunk, divorced and on the run. Bad Blake has never pulled a no-show in his whole damned life. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not even in a fucking bowling alley backed by a bunch of hippies. Bad takes the joint and takes a long drag. Bad looks at t joint and takes one more drag.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You sure they ain't paying you more than they're paying me? INT. THE SPARE ROOM BOWLING ALLEY —- LATER 14 * The bar and stage area are dark. Bad adjusts his guitar a steps back off stage, nearly falling. He nods to Tony. Tony steps on the light switch and illuminates the stage area. The band moves into an up-tempo version of "Somebod Else." At the end of the first chorus, Tony moves to the microph

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the Spare Room is proud to present country recording star 'The Wrangler of Love," Mr. Bad Blake. Bad steps forward to where the light is supposed to be on but misjudges. Only his guitar is in the light. He takes step into the light and swings into his jazzy melody, sim but quick and light, full of triplets that sound harder t play than they really are.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (to the band) * Go to C...Now to F. * Bad steps to the mic and starts the song.. *

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to be somebody Now I'm sombebody else Who I'll be tomorrow Is anybody's guess... After another half minute of the song, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad's shirt is sweat-stained. He's becoming more drunk by the moment. The whiskey starts to push back up in his throat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how good it is to be here in Pueblo...If I've learned anything over the years, it's give you folks what you want to hear...This song is for all of you who've been good to me for such a long spell. But I also want to send it out special to a couple of my dear friends, Bill and Beverly. God, I think the world of them. Bad begins a Waylon-esque version of "I Don't Know". The applause start again. The band comes in behind Bad and fo a pocket for him to fit in a a melody. BILL (from the liq store) and BEVERLY WILSON, in matching shirts, jeans, and boots, beam. After half a minute, Bad unplugs his guitar,stumbles, and then lands on one knee on top of his amp. He looks up to a red amplifier light, pulsing in the dark. He then stead himself and crosses to a cracked alley door behind the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 17 18 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad's outside in the back alley, on his knees, holding th rim of a garbage can. He's cold and shivering. He wipes h face with a handkerchief, then check's to see if he's kep his outfit clean. It's soaked with sweat. In the background, we hear Tony and his boys play their hearts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad crosses to his amp and watches as Tony mightily overc a solo. He picks up his guitar, and just as Tony finishes a round of warm applause, Bad starts in on the same solo. musicianship is smoother, more efficient, and much more Masterly. Tony meekly steps back downstage as Bad finishe the guitar lesson. The crowd roars their approval . As the Renegades finish the jam, Bad unsteadily steps to microphone.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: It's been wonderful being with you tonight. I want to dedicate this show to Jo Ann, bless her pretty little heart. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You all drive safely now and Lord * willing, we'll get together again real soon. Good night. Bad makes eye contact with JO ANN. She sits next to a tal angular man with a high-crowned hat. Tony then steps to t microphone.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the star of the show. Let's hear it for the great Bad Blake. Large round of applause as Bad plays a quick riff and ste into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light starts to come through the window next to the bed. turns over next to JO ANN. Her makeup has worn off,and he hair is tangled around her hand. She looks older and draw Bad dresses quietly and exits into another day. EXT. ESTABLISHING - SANTA FE, NEW MEXICO —- DAY 20 * The buildings are low and nestled into the hills. It's fl as hell. Bad, listening to FREDDIE FENDER'S "QUE", pulls Suburban into the LAND OF ENCHANTMENT MOTEL. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad exits the MOTEL OFFICE and walks toward his room. A D CLERK exits the office and calls out to Bad.

dialogues.speaker: DESK CLERK
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake? A Mr. Jack Greene sent this. The desk clerk hands Bad an envelope. He opens it to find hundred dollars. He smiles at the desk clerk and pockets INT. LAND OF ENCHANTMENT MOTEL —- LATER 22 * Bad sits on the bed. His guitar unstrung, he meticulously polishes the fretboard with linseed oil. One has to wonde how many sets of strings Bad has worn out in his career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just before Bad enters the bar, he stops to listen to his band. Someone is playing PIANO, instrumental in the vein Charlie Rich.  24 Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad stops inside the doorway as WESLEY BARNES, a large ma who's sweating profusely, plays the piano beautifully. Ba stops playing and wipes his brow as he spots Bad. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 14 24

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Sounds real good. Real good. Been a long time since I've played with a good piano player.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY BARNES
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. Blake. Means the world to me. I'm Wesley Barnes. Wesley wipes his hands on his trousers and moves to Bad. Bad looks

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Mighty fine, Wesley. You work before?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY BARNES
dialogues.text: When I was kid. I just do this for fun. Just for fun and a couple of extra dollars.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Well, it's real nice to run into someone on the road who really is good. It's going to be a pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY BARNES
dialogues.text: I appreciate it. around the bar. No one else is here.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY BARNES
dialogues.text: The rest of the guys are running late. Day jobs.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: As long as you're here, we'll be fine. Wesley beams. Bad uncases his guitar and attaches the str After a beat, Wesley nervously approaches Bad.

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY BARNES
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a favor, Mr. Blake?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Bad, buddy, Bad. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY BARNES
dialogues.text: I hate to impose, especially since we just met. But you see, I have this niece, and she's a writer. She's trying to be a writer. She writes local here in Santa Fe. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: WESLEY BARNES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean it's not the New York Times, anyway, she'd love to do an interview with you. An article about you for the paper. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 25 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 15

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Hell, I haven't done one for years, but you send your little niece around. I'll be glad to help her out. INT. LAND OF ENCHANTMENT MOTEL —- LATER 25 Bad is fresh from a shower. He's wrapped in a towel. His service dinner steams on a nearby table. There's a knock at the door. He opens it to find a woman appears to be in her early thirties, with dark hair. She' wearing a fresh denim shirt and creased jeans. This is JE CRADDOCK, Wesley Barnes' niece.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake? I've come at a bad time. Bad's nearly naked.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Jean Craddock, The Sun Scene... Wesley Barnes' niece. I've come for the interview. This is a bad time.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: No. Yes. Shit. I'm having dinner. I just got out of the shower.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'll come back. When's a good time?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Hell, just wait outside a minute. Let me get dressed. Bad closes the door and grabs at his clothes. His hair is and combed back. He puts on denim jeans and a Western shi He looks around the room. Sheet music and clothes strewn about. He straightens the bed and crosses to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I should have called.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Come in. He looks at her closely. She's a little older than first thought. Maybe late THIRTIES. She has a TAPE RECORDER in hand and a CAMERA over her shoulder. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No pictures. You want some steak? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 16

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No. How about later?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Which?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Pictures. Maybe on stage?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Be all right. Mind if I eat? She sits across the room and sets the TAPE RECORDER on th dresser. Bad cuts a piece of steak and bites into it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Let's see. You always dress for dinner? The chewed steak lodges in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Thinking about you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You think any about me?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm finishing the article.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I know. Bad rearranges himself in the tiny phone booth. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Listen. I have a couple of days before I've got to be back in Houston. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like to stop off and see you. (long pause) Jean?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You're not making this easy, girl. You want me to stop by or not?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (long pause) Yes... Bad holds on to the phone after Jean's hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad cruises the lonely desert highways of New Mexico. The brush at the roadside grows coarse and dense. The truck starts to KNOCK as he climbs in altitude.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Shit. Bad wearily looks out over the unforgiving landscape. INT. SUBURBAN —- NEW MEXICO HIGHWAY —- LATE AFTERNOON 58 Bad cruises along the highway, just outside of Santa Fe. fading sun illuminates the aspens of the SANGRE de CRISTO MOUNTAINS. He starts to nod off to sleep, then closes his eyes for a SPLIT SECOND. Bad hears the crunch of the TIRES on GRAVEL and then an e THUMP. He sees grass and brush and a WIRE FENCE coming at in slow motion. Bad moves his foot to the brakes and turns the wheel. The truck bounces across the scrub brush, through the WIRE FE Bad's truck pulls scrub brush as it head for a TREE. He t the wheel as hard as he can, but the IMPACT sends him acr the wheel and into the WINDSHIELD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad's head is cold and his hand hurts. He sees his hat on floor next to him in a pile of sheet music and a Styrofoa hamburger box. Around him, everything is wet and sticky. Things spin and his world implodes.  Pink Revision 12/7/2009 48h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out cold, Bad lays against the steering wheel. A hand tou his shoulder. An older HISPANIC MAN leans into Bad's truc (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 61 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 49

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: You okay? Bad leans his head back against the top of the seat and slowly nods his head. The man opens the door of the truck holding onto Bad's shoulder with his other hand.

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: Can you get out?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Something's wrong with my leg.

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC MAN
dialogues.text: Grab on to me. The man is much smaller than Bad, grips Bad hard and lift him from the seat. Bad reaches out, and puts his arm arou the man's shoulder. They do a slow, intricate waltz out o the truck. The man carries Bad to a pickup as it idles, its tailligh flashing red. INT. SANTA FE HOSPITAL —- THE NEXT DAY 61 The vertical blinds, the bed rails, and curtains slowly c into focus. A BANDAGE is wrapped around Bad's forehead an plaster CAST covers his left ankle.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Where am I? A NURSE in her mid-forties stands over Bad.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake, you're in Santa Fe. You have a broken ankle. You also have a concussion. Bad winces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Can I leave?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: When you can leave is up to the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Today?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Probably not. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 49h

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Get me the doctor.  62 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kind looking DOCTOR in his late sixties sits on the edg the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: The problem isn't your ankle, Mr. Blake. It will heal cleanly..The problem is your general condition, or extreme lack of it... Bad looks away to break the doctor's stare.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The kinds of stuff we're talking about here-emphysema, heart failure, cancer, an extremely good chance of a stroke-are more debilitating than quickly and cleanly fatal. They'll kill you, there's no mistaking that, but they're going to do it slowly, painfully, and humiliatingly. You're going to end up helpless as a child, in all probability. Bad still doesn't respond. The doctor now stands.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake, are you going to talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Look. I have other patients to see. The doctor heads for the door. Just as he's about to exit turns back to Bad.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Obviously, you don't want to hear this, and I understand it, but when I see a case like yours, I have to say something. You're a fifty-seven year old man who is rapidly starting to wear out. You get no exercise, you clearly eat anything at all, and let's not kid ourselves about this one: you're an alcoholic. I'll take care of your leg and give you something for your cholesterol, but you have to stop smoking, stop drinking, and lose twenty-five pounds. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor and nurse leave. Bad looks to the PATIENT in t bed next to him, who's mouth is agape. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 63 64 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 51

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'd give up cholesterol and salt, and kiss his ass for a drink. EXT. SANTA FE HOSPITAL —- THE NEXT DAY 63 JEAN wheels Bad out of the hospital in a WHEELCHAIR. She has that what the hell am I doing look on her face. B is dressed in the clothes he was wearing when he had the wreck. The left leg of his jeans is slit up to the knee. has his guitar and left boot on his lap, is talking a blu streak, and feeling no pain..

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: It'll just be for a day or two. You don't need some old gimp hanging around. And if I'm half as good at being laid up as I think I'm going to be, I'd..

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You need to hush now. Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What? Am I rambling? Must be them little blue pills. Wonder if I could a get a prescription or two?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad's flat on his back in Jean's bed. His foot is propped on two pillows. On the table beside him are his cigarette and a bottle of JACK DANIEL'S. He can hear Jean move through the house. On the televisio that sits at the foot of the bed, two women talk. One fig back tears. Bad hops to the other side of the room, where guitar is propped against the chair, grabs it and scoots to the bed. For a bit, Bad just plays. He moves from harmonic to melo and back, responding to signals he's not conscious of. It as though his fingers have taken charge and all he needs do, must do, is listen to what they are doing.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Your heart's on the loose You rolled them sevens with nothing to lose... This ain't the place...for the weary kind... Jean peaks her head in. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You called...all your shots Shootin eight balls...at The corner truck stop Somehow this don't feel like home anymore... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean lights up.

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know that song?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I think so but I can't remember who did it.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: That's the way it is. The good ones are the ones you're sure you've heard before.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You wrote that?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am. Just now.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: It's so unfair.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Some people would trade 10 years of their life to be able to do something like that. And it just pours out of you. (turning to go) I'm going to get Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I can go to a hotel or..

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You're a very dense person sometimes. I don't want you to go.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Then what's wrong? You're writing bed! g a song on my bed! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And now I'll have to keep it for the rest of my life and every time I lay down I'll hear that beautiful song. And you'll be out there running around, not even remembering a day that I can't forget. Her tears flow. Bad takes a drink and holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: If I could walk, I'd come to you. She comes and plops down on the bed. He holds her hand helplessly then offers her a sip of whiskey. She takes it

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the hospital, I thought about who to call, who I knew that really gives a damn about me. Then I thought, who do I really want to see? I won't forget this day, darlin', I promise. He kisses her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad sits on a porch swing talking on the phone to Jack Greene. His leg propped up on a table.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: No, Jack, I wasn't drinking. I just fell asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack curls a small dumbbell as he talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What are you doing back in Santa Fe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 Jean crosses to a table with two cups of coffee and place them next to a half-empty glass of whiskey. She takes it and then sits next to Bad.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Visiting a friend. 65 66

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: A, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bad puts his arm around her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 54

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Can you drive?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Pretty soon.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I want to get you back out there.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Jack, if you found out your sister was turning five-dollar tricks, you'd over book her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Remind me to put you in a couple of comedy clubs...Just so you know, I have a contract here, offering you seventy-five thousand dollars advance for an album to be recorded at a future date. Plus another twenty thousand for first refusal rights to all songs written or co- written by you over the next two years.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Ditto. This is now your best year in the last seven. And thank Tommy Sweet for it. So ease up on him...Talk to you in Houston, and don't marry your friend!

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I ain't getting married. Bad hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You want me to call him and tell him I'm not about to marry you.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You might have waited until I asked before you turned me down. Jean kisses him on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm going to get Buddy. I told him he could draw on your cast. She looks into him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 67 68 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 55

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going to sleep on the fold out. It'd be too confusing for him.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: No, I'll sleep on it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You need to be in a bed. (off his protest) It's all right. I want to do it. Will you do something for me?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Name it. She glances at the glass of whiskey on the table.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Don't drink in front of him. Bad stares into her for a moment then blinks.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: No problem. She kisses him and enters the house. He looks around, yaw and empties the glass. EXT. FIELD — LATE DAY 67 Bad leans on his crutches and stares up at...a heater roa FIRE into a huge orange and purple striped BALOON that is lifting off! Jean and Buddy are on board. Buddy is nearly beside himse with excitement. Jean is a lot less happy. Buddy waves frantically at Bad. Bad snorts and waves back just as frantically. Jean's hea catches in her throat as they go higher and higher. As they lift away, Bad leans back against the car, stares at the bottom of the basket, reaches into his jacket for flask, and has a much needed drink. His hands are shaking looks down at Big Bird drawn on his cast and has another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad watches as Jean and Buddy climb down the steps from t balloon. Buddy runs to him, talking so fast Bad can't eve understand him. Jean is glowing clear through.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You have to do it! It's another world up there! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad just grins at them. He knows the feeling.  69 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elegant restaurant is emptying out. Bad and Jean sit an outdoor fireplace. Bad's Big Bird cast is up on a chai There are two empty wine bottles on the table and a third almost gone. Jean is still glowing and beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I would've never gone up in that thing on my own. Thank you. Buddy's probably jabbering about it in his sleep. Bad pours the last of the wine.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: This whole domestic thing is pretty intense. Is it always like that?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean? You've been married a bunch.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Yeah but, I didn't wuh.. (darkens/looks outside) I've got a twenty-eight-year-old son, Jean. I haven't seen him since he was four.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (look/long beat) Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I don't know. His mom, Marge, lives in Marfa, Texas. I don't know what he looks like, what he's doing. I didn't teach him how to ride his bike or drive a car.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Wasn't there... even when I was there. Hell of a thing, be this old and not know anything about your own boy.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I couldn't live if I lost Buddy. For the first time, we see real emotion in Bad's face. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: That's the damnedest part. You do live.  70 71 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean, still quite drunk from dinner, checks on Buddy, kis his hair, and comes out into the living room. The fold ou couch is open. She looks at it, looks at her bedroom door which is half open. She crosses to the door, peeks in and sees Bad sitting on the edge of the bed in his clothes, drinking JD. She knocks lightly. He puts the glass down a looks over.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You need help getting undressed?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Be a lot more satisfying if you did.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe we can get away by ourselves this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What's today?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I can't make it 'til the weekend. She blows him a kiss and begins to back out. Bad grabs at hungrily. Bad brings Jean onto the bed and unbuttons her blouse. They kiss passionately, drunkenly. Just as Bad tr to lay Jean down she pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No...no, not now. She kisses his hair and slides back on the bed. She can't escape his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad wakes up, grabs his constitutional drink, swings his out of the bed, and the cast clunks heavily on the floor. That hurts. Bad's crutches lean against the wall, across the room. Slowly, he stands, weight on his right leg. Then he shift his left, but it's too painful. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets down and crawls across the floor. When he reaches dresser, he gets the crutches to move to a WICKER HAMPER where Jean's draped his pants. He puts his weight on the hamper. Seems sturdy enough. He sits gingerly on the hamper and pulls his jeans on his le leg. As he tries the other leg, the top of the hamper GIV IN and Bad falls in, ass first.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Ah, hell! Jean runs in, sees the empty bed, looks around and spots in the hamper.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! He's on the floor, his left leg up, sticking out of the broken hamper, his right leg splayed out and resting on t of an aralia palm in a ceramic pot. His pants are caught around his knees.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: How the hell do I look?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You really want to know?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'm all right. Get me up.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Give me a second..

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Help me up, damn it! Bad tries to get out of the smashed hamper as Jean has a laughing fit. BUDDY walks in and goes over to Bad as Bad tries to wiggle his jeans up to his hips. Buddy pulls the palm plant off Bad's foot.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Want biscuits? Jean walks out, laughing her heart out.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: For such a sweet lady, your mother has a very deviant sense of humor. A FLASH from a camera lights up the room..  Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 72 Buddy helps mix the biscuit batter with Bad. Jean hurries and out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I've got to go down to the paper. I'll drop Buddy off at the day-care center and-

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Why don't you just leave him here with me? She stops and stares at him. Jean puts

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You don't want to baby-sit. Besides, Buddy will want to see his friends at-

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I want to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: There you go. We want to stay.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And do what?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Man stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Man stuff. some dishes into the sink. She is obviously torn.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: With your ankle, it's probably not best.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Aw, Mom.. Bad hobbles over beside her and nudges her.

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please. Be a good thing for all of us. We'll be fine, I promise. She tries to cover her concern as he kisses her lightly o the nose.  Pink Revision 12/7/2009 59h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad grabs his crutches and moves about pretty well. Buddy right beside him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You play cards? (off Buddy's puzzled look) Then, maybe we ought to go out and see what kind of trouble we can get into.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Big trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swings, teeter-totters, and slides abound. Bad pushes Bud in the swing. Buddy's all smiles. Bad's enjoying himself, too. We get the sense he wished he'd done more of this in life. He's surprised when he looks down and sees his hands shak badly. He starts to reach into his jacket for a drink the stops and tries to tough it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean comes in and anxiously calls. Nobody answers. It's suddenly hard to breathe. As she starts to search the hou Buddy and Bad clamber through the door. They are both inexplicably dirty.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: It was fun, nobody died, don't ask. Buddy obviously had a great time. As he runs to Jean grinning, Bad slips into the bedroom and heads straight f the bottle. His hands are shaking so badly he can hardly the cap off. EXT. HOTEL BALCONY - TAOS, NEW MEXICO — MORNING 76 A serene hotel in the woods with a magnificent view of Pu Peak. Drink in hand, Bad sits on a lounge chair in a whit robe. He stares out at the golden-hued Aspens. Jean steps onto the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Join me, darlin. Jean slips onto a lounge beside him. She glances at his h empty whiskey glass. Then, after a lengthy beat:

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (holding up the glass) I don't want you worrying about this. I'm real good at it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I didn't say anything. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You didn't have to. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 61

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I am worried...Though, I'm sure you've heard that before. Bad sets the glass down. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Jeannie, I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Can you? Bad doesn't respond. Jean turns and looks into him.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I want this to work, Bad. I do. I just don't know how it can if you continue like this. Day and night...It's like living with a rattlesnake..

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And I don't want Buddy around it. That much I know.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I heard you the first time. I won't drink around him... And trust me, I've been doing this a long time. It don't affect me like you might think. We got too good a thing for me to screw it up. Jean starts to respond, but Bad puts his index finger up her lips.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: It'll be okay. Bad grabs her hand and squeezes. He then pulls it up to h mouth and kisses it gingerly. All Jean can do is nod. Bad looks out over the vast expanse and decides to change gea

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've logged over a thousand miles around these mountains but I don't think I've ever seen them. Another thing I missed..

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You could find your son if you wanted to. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What would he say? What would I say? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 77 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 62

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Whatever it was, it would be better than nothing, wouldn't it? He looks into her.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What about you, what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: About anything.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Write a book.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: About me?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You wish. I'm going to write about what I know.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I think I want to be in it then.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'm gonna need to get to Houston then get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'm gonna miss the hell out of you and that boy.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (turns and look into him) Then we'll miss the hell out of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad's Suburban looks better than it did, though traces of bondo still remain. Buddy sits forlornly on the bumper as Jean puts Bad's guitar into the back. Bad musses Buddy's hair, as he's having a hard time with this goodbye, too. Buddy gets up abruptly and runs into the house. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 63

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Ya'll come to Houston, okay? I'm booked there for the next four months. Nights only, so I'm off all day. We'll-

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I took some time off for our trip so I don't know if I can get away now.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Try. I'll take Buddy down to NASA. He'll love them rockets and things.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: That means no.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No. It means we'll see.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Lot of things to write about in Houston. Me.. and other stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: That's more than a visit.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Running off the road was one of the best things that's ever happened to me. Think about that. Bad embraces Jean for a long beat. When they part, Jean p his old bag into the Suburban and pulls out a near empty bottle of JACK DANIEL'S.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear it, darlin’. She looks into him and her eyes fill.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I lay awake at night asking myself why is it okay to care so deeply for you...

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: And? She suddenly kisses him passionately and steps back. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: 63A
dialogues.text: 11 (CONT'D) (2) m7

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And...I just want you to know that I'm not giving you a hard time. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It just freaks me out, okay?..You be careful out there. She turns and walks into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearing Houston, the landscape flattens. Downtown Houston directly in front of him, all vertical light. The city is stunning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad exits his Suburban and approaches his one-story, bric ranch house. The house has seen better days, but looks as though it was a source of neighborhood pride at one time. unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the coffee table, there are stacks of mail. Advertisin fliers, a few letters, a couple of bills. One large BROWN ENVELOPE with the return address: IRS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few stars are faintly visible against the overcast and reflected lights of the city. Bad sits on the porch with an acoustic guitar. He begins working his way up and down the fretboard until a note op a door. He touches a melody he instantly likes. It then c as easily to him as an old song recalled after years.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Your body aches From playing your guitar and sweatin' out the hate... The days and nights all feel the same... Bad writes the chords on a yellow pad. INT. WAYNE'S BAR -— HOUSTON - DAY 82 Bad hobbles into this dark roadhouse. As he makes his way the back of the bar, we see a stage off in the corner. Bad makes his way past trash cans waiting to be emptied, boxes of empty beer bottles. WAYNE KRAMER, stocking glass late sixties and all cowboy, greets Bad.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Jesus, Bad. You look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I know. It's all on account of the toilets I have to play in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oe Oe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 65 82

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Heard about the wreck. It's a damn shame... Framed on the wall is a PICTURE of Bad.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Could have been worse. How's business?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Since you've been on the road, it's crap.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You ever cleaned this place, you might figure out how to run this business.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I clean this place, I might find out that we're both broke. How was the road?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Doesn't get any shorter. It makes coming back here look good. Wayne takes a BOTTLE from the shelf and pours a drink for and himself. They sit at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Something interesting must of happened.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Met a woman in Santa Fe.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Doesn't come as a real surprise.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: A good one. A real good one.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Santa Fe's a hell of a way from here.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Eight hundred and seventy-nine miles.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Tough trip for a man who has to work Saturday nights. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad finishes his whiskey. Good to be in the company of an friend.  83 84 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad sits on the sofa strumming his guitar. After a few chords, he begins to hum and write on his legal pad.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: The whiskey has been...A thorn in your side that doesn't forgive The highway that calls for your heart inside... This ain't no place for the weary kind This ain't no place to lose your mind This ain't no place to fall behind Pick up your crazy heart and give it...one more try Bad plays the melody as though it were a second skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad heads for the PHONE. Underneath the phone lies a stac PHONE BOOKS. He pulls out a tattered copy of the MARFA, TEXAS, phone book. A book he's referred to on many occasi Bad thumbs through to a page he has dog-eared. His finger traces down the page and stops at a CIRCLED phone number. picks up the phone and dials. It rings several times, the

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Yeah, hello. Is this Steven Reynolds?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes. Who's calling?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Well, actually, buddy, I'm on a bit of a hunting trip here. I'm trying to find a Mary Jo Reynolds from Lima, Ohio, who lived in Nashville, Tennessee, from nineteen eighty to eighty-five. Are you related to her, by any chance? A moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: She was my mother. Was? Bad's breath becomes constricted. His body goes cold When he speaks, his voice is between a croak and a whispe (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 Pink Revision (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I can't hear you. Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (whispers) Your father. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Bad Blake in Houston. I'm your father. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I just wanted to.. I don't know I'm shocked to hear your voice, I.. (beat) You said "was". Mary Jo's dead?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Two years ago in October.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Everything.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear..

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I want to see you, Steven. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I don't think so. 12/7/2009 67 84 (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Well. (beat) Will you think about it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I probably won't be able to help it.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Look, just take down my number.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It's on my Caller-I.D.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Okay. Sleep on it, think about it. I really would like to talk.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Imagine that. Bad hangs up and stares out into space. Hardest call he e had to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad can't sleep. His beside clock reads three-thirty. He sits up in bed, lights off, with a bottle. He takes a lon pull and stares at the ceiling fan. Sweat beads on his forehead. Bad looks out to a street lamp that illuminates his room. Slowly his eyes close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun's harsh rays penetrate his blinds. Bad's crashed in bed. A nearly empty bottle of JACK rests on his bedsid table. The PHONE rings. Bad, hung over, reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy sits on the floor with a jigsaw puzzle strewn about (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I made the cars go real fast. Real fast, then the jeep went around the corner and it went BOOM. Buddy's voice hits the center of his head like a fist. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision (CONT'D) (2)

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (struggling) Buddy, you got the cars?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I make them go faster than anybody and then they crash! JEAN grabs the phone from Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He's trying to say thank you. But you've got to stop sending all these toys. He thinks you're Santa Claus now. Bad rolls over in bed. He looks terrible.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I just want him to know I'm thinking of him, darlin'. You thinking about me? Bad tries to sit up but thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. Bad takes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I called him last night, Jeannie, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And?!

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Marge, his mom, is dead.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: He didn't want to talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: No, it's.. I don't blame him, I.. (nauseous ) Jean.. I don't feel too good, can I call you back? I gotta.. 12/7/2009 69 87 Bad drops the phone. When his foot hits the floor, he realizes his knees can't carry him in a straight line. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to walk and bangs into the dresser and then drop the floor. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 88 89 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 70

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crawls into the bathroom on hands and knees. He hangs the rim of the toilet. When he begins wretching, the cryi starts and he can't stop either of them. Finally, Bad falls to the bathroom floor. He's out cold. Still on the phone, Jean has heard it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne stands in the doorway. He turns on the light and lo to Bad, splayed out on the floor by the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: We're goin' fishin'. Bad lifts his head. He looks like death warmed over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne and Bad are seated in Wayne's boat near the bank. T moon is full and casts a beautiful glow across the lake.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Hand me one more of those barley pops and I believe I'll be settled for a while. Bad opens the beer and takes a long swallow.

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hate to admit it, but this was a damn good idea. They drift at anchor, not worrying about their lines, drinking and smoking. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just sent what might be my best song ever to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: To record?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Yep. It's one of those you hate to give up.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Why'd you do it?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Because he's paying me awful good. He's already in the studio recording it. Stopped off in L.A. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Hope he don't butcher it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 90 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 71

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: He can't fuck it up. It's that good. They both laugh, knowing it's the truth. Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: So your boy didn't want to talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: No, and I can't blame him. I was wrong. I had no right to call him.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You were wrong twenty years ago. And you've been wrong since, because you didn't call him. But you weren't wrong when you did. He was wrong, not you.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I went twenty years without trying to find him, Wayne. He's right. Too little, too late.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: This time you did it. You were late in doing it, but you did it. It's over and you've changed it. So, don't give up now that you're on the right track. Keep after him.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: He's the only thing I got. At that, we begin a slow pullback from the boat. After a lengthy beat, Wayne softly hums and then begins to sing t Gospel hymn "Wings of a Dove." The moon's glow illuminate the lake as we FADE OUT. INT. JEAN'S HOUSE - KITCHEN —- DAY 90 Jean stands on her back porch looking out at the mountain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 91 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 72

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad moves about the kitchen prepping his supper. Spices strewn about the counter-tops.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (surprised) Hey. Yeah, I'm fine. Why?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You didn't sound fine the other day. You sounded like you were dying a slow death.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You heard that? Hell, I'm sorry. Must have been something I ate. It's clear that Jean doesn't buy this. Over the phone we the fish popping and crackling in the skillet.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I called to say that I've got four days off at the end of the month. And that we might come, but I'm not sure it would be such a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Hell, it's a great idea. Why would you say that? Jean doesn't initially respond. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're okay, Bad? I'm very worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Don't you waste a minute of your time worrying about me. There's nothing wrong that a little visit wouldn't cure. How's ol' Buddy boy?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: So you're really coming? A beat as she unconsciously twirls her hair. Then: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: If you want us to. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 91 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 73

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: God, yes!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: ...Okay... Bye. As Jean makes her way into her house, it's clear that she struggling with her decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad, all smiles, hangs up. The catfish is filleted, bread and in the frying pan when the phone rings yet again.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Just come, okay, I don't care about anything else.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Is this Bad Blake's residence?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Yeah, who..

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It's Steven Reynolds. A beat, then it jolts Bad as it registers.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Steven!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I've been thinking. (beat) I guess maybe I do want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Sure. Hell, yes. When? Where?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I could come to Houston one of these days or you could come here.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Ten ours. I guess, eleven yours. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: What are you doing now? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 92 93 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 74

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Watching football.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'll be there for the late game.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: This afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Bet your sweet ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad hobbles out the door of a TAXI CAB. He's carrying an overnight bag on his shoulder. He looks around, unsure wh exactly he is looking for, but sure he'll recognize him. A YOUNG MAN with brown hair and an open-collared shirt wa down the sidewalk toward Bad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (nods at crutches) What happened? Bad just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's Steven. Tears well up in Bad's eyes as he looks at Steven and nod

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I can sure see your mother in your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: (a look/then) I'll take your bag. They shake hands awkwardly. Steven takes the bag and they walk back up the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what's with the crutches?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I thought if I got crippled up you might feel sorry for me. Steven grabs his arm and leads him toward the steps of hi modest ranch house. Awkward beat, then: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: How long you been in Houston? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 94 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 75

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Comin' up on sixteen years.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Why not Nashville?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I play in a club and have some friends there. Nashville's over.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Is it hard not being in the big time anymore?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (a tense look) I miss the money, but there's a whole world of people who don't like what I do for a living. I always did. I wouldn't mind one more go around with the money, but I don't know.. Another awkward silence as they reach the porch.

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What made you change your mind and call me?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: My wife.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Oh. Wife? Jesus... I mean good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven leads Bad over to a sofa and gently helps him down The house is sparsely furnished but tidy. Bad takes it in

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: This is nice. Real nice.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It's a roof over our head. Just then, MARISSA, a tall, thin blonde in a T-shirt and shorts crosses to Bad and reaches out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARISSA
dialogues.text: Mr. Blake. Don't get up. I'm Marissa.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'm standing in my mind. Call me Bad, please. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 95 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 76

dialogues.speaker: MARISSA
dialogues.text: Can I get you some water, Coke, beer?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Anything stronger?

dialogues.speaker: MARISSA
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Beer's just right.

dialogues.speaker: MARISSA
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I'm just finishing dinner. Steven turns on the game and follows Marissa into the kitchen, leaving Bad alone on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they finish supper, Marissa brings out boxes of pictur Bad sorts through them. A picture of Mary Jo in front of store.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Mom was a clothing buyer. Bad glances at a picture of Marge's wedding.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She married Jeff, another buyer at the store. He tosses the picture aside and picks up a picture of Bad playing guitar to Steven on a blue velvet sofa. The skinn kid, grinning, with a beer in his hand, is TOMMY SWEET. Bad smiles as he comes across pictures of Steven from inf to man. School pictures, vacation pictures, boy scouts. Steven in football gear. Bad comes across a picture of MARY JO and himself just af a show. Bad in a wide-lapeled western suit, Mary Jo ina dress that billowed around her body. She ages subtly, hol her looks through most of the other pictures. Bad comes across one of Mary Jo in the hospital, near the end, where she looks like an old woman. Bad stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In case you're wondering, she died of lymphoma. (off Bad's silence) Took six months. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oe  95 (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 77 95

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: (staring at the picture) If you don't mind me asking, what did she tell you about me?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: She never said a bad word about you. Bad jerks and looks at Steven. He finally lays the pictur down. Steven looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I was a kid I used to brag to my friends that you were my father.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You did?!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Then you started showing up on the news for.. things.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Well. I don't remember much about some of those times. (beat) The road's killed a lot of people. Made a lot more crazy.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: So it was the road that did all those things?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You don't know what it's like year in year out..

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I guess not. Same as you don't know what it was like back here.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I know I.. missed things, Steven.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You mean like my life?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Yeah but, I.. Marissa rises from the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARISSA
dialogues.text: Let me get you guys another beer. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I know I can't do anything about your mother. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink Revision 12/7/2009 78

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What would you do if you could?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I don't know. Tell her.. tell her I always loved her in my way.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Just out of curiosity, what way is that? Bad stares at him, then digs in his pocket for a sheaf of bills in a GOLD MONEY CLIP.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I bought this clip on your eighteenth birthday. I was going to send it to you, but I didn't know how... where ya'll were exactly. I've been carrying it ever since. Bad holds it out. Steven looks at it, then takes it and h it by its edges as if it were dangerous or delicate. It's battered and scratched. He flips it back to Bad. It lands his lap.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You better keep it around your money.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: But I bought it for you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, but I gave up wanting anything from you a long time ago. Bad looks at the money clip in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Why did you call me back then?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I told you. Marissa talked me into it.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: You must have wanted to be talked into it or..

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: +..or maybe I was just curious.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Well, I am too. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 Pink Revision 12/7/2009 719

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: C'mon. Do you realize you haven't asked a damn thing about me since you got here? Bad's face is white. He gets his crutches and works his w up.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Appreciate it if you'd call me a cab. Bad starts to make his way to the door. He turns to Steve

dialogues.speaker: BAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think it was easy, doing this?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You have got to be one of the most self-involved son-of-a-bitches on earth. You never even called me. Not once. Ever. How the hell is that even possible? Everything was all about you then and it's all about you now. Steven crosses but Bad grabs him by the arn.

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something: there may have been a day or two in that twenty years that I didn't think about you, but by God, I don't remember a one. Steven pulls free of Bad's grasp.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I don't care what you thought, I care what you did! Do you really think you can explain away twenty years of doing nothing?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
dialogues.text: I'm not making excuses, I'm just saying..

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Saying what? What the hell are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: BAD
